controls:
Oxygen content shall be tested. The acceptable range is 19.5 to 23.5 percent.
Test for combustible gas and vapors. Ensure that you are within the Explosion Limits. Record readings on the Entry Permit.
Safe operating levels can be determined from the Permissible Exposure Level (PEL) as listed in OSHA 29 CFR 1910.1000.handle

Complete the Non-Permit Required Confined Space Entry Form.

If the work site contains permit-required confined spaces, danger signs stating "DANGER - CONFINED SPACE - ENTER BY PERMIT ONLY" shall be posted to inform employees of the existence and location of the spaces. Bilingual signs shall be posted as necessary.

[internalCustomer] Employees do not enter or conduct work in Permit Required Confined Space. If our Competent Person determines that the area is Permit Required, we will sub the work out.

Determine if any penetrations into the space are active or have the potential for activity.
All penetrations into the space will be LOTO to prevent engulfment.
Refer to the LOTO/COHE program under separate cover.

Permit Required Confined Spaces may be reclassified as non-permit spaces under the following circumstances:

The space has no actual or potential atmospheric hazards OR all hazards within the space are eliminated without entry into the space.
Employees shall wear a personal monitor at all time.
The COHE Program shall be followed for engulfment
If a hazard returns, employees shall evacuate the space and the space shall be reevaluated.

Set up CAZ.
Post signs stating "DANGER - CONFINED SPACE" to inform others of the existence and location of the confined spaces.
As a team, identify and mitigate potential hazards
Define roles and verify competency.
Set up rescue equipment
Identify fall protection tie off spot

Using a blower, introduce comfort air if necessary.
Retest the air and document the new readings.

hazards:
Engulfment
Fire/Electrical hazards
Atmospheric hazards
Entry and Exit obstructions
controls:
The attendant shall remain at the entry point while personnel are inside any confined space unless relived by a trained and authorized individual.
The attendant shall ensure that only authorized personnel enter the confined space and the CAZ.
Attendants shall not perform any other work activities except that they may also serve as the attending supervisor.
Establish communication method between entrant and attendant.
If an emergency or other unplanned event takes place during the course of work, the Confined Space Work Permit is void.
The attendant and entry supervisor have the authority to discontinue work activities at any time.
100% fall protection must be maintained inside the CAZ or until hazard is eliminated

hazards:
Working in the dark
Unable to see or recognize hazards
controls: [internalCustomer] is responsible for task lighting of at least (5) foot candles of light in the area where the task is being performed.

100% fall protection must be maintained inside the CAZ or until hazard is eliminated
The area surrounding the confined space shall be clean of materials, equipment, scraps, and debris.
The supervisor responsible for the confined space work shall inspect the work location to ensure cleanup of materials, tools, and other items is complete.
LOTO is removed only when work is completed.
The confined space permit is closed and signed off by supervisor.

hazards:
Failure of the monitor
Inaccurate readings
Potential Exposures
controls:
Before testing the air in a confined space, you must perform a bump test on the gas monitor.
Expose the monitor to a known concentration of test gas and wait for the alarm to activate.
If the instrument's response is within an acceptable tolerance range of the actual concentration, then its calibration is verified.
If it does not respond as expected, it will need to be fully calibrated before it can be used.

NEVER ATTEMPT A RESCUE BY GOING INTO THE CONFINED SPACE UNLESS TRAINED IN RESCUE PROCEDURES.
To facilitate non-entry rescue, retrieval systems or methods shall be used.
Inspect retrieval equipment prior to potential use.
Each authorized entrant shall use a full body harness with a retrieval lifeline attached.
Develop a rescue plan specific to the space prior to entry.
Arrange for entry rescue services to be on-call and familiar with the task.
All workers will be trained on the rescue plan prior to the start of work.

task: Identify and escort crane to lifting locations
hazards:
Struck by
Pinch points
Overhead power lines
Slips, trip and falls
controls:
Inspect path of travel to be used by crane and identify any overhead hazards and hazards in path and remove or direct crane around them.
Conduct a safety briefing with workers who will be involved in guiding crane into position and identify hazards found in pre-inspection of path of travel.
Control pedestrian traffic while crane is being moved into position.
Do not place yourself between fixed objects and crane while crane is being moved into position.
Once the crane is in place 3 trucks at a time will enter for unloading. While they are being unloaded the area will be flagged off so as to keep unauthorized personnel out of the swing zone and out from under the suspended load. The area will be posted with warning signs.

hazards:
Rigging failure
Caught between/struck by
Insufficient Support and/or Space f+or Load
controls:
Keep all persons clear of areas under the loads while landing associated equipment or materials.
Ensure landing areas are clear of debris and built according to design/specifications sufficient for specific equipment load weights.
Control rotation of load with multiple tag lines.

hazards:
Equipment failure
Shifting load
Pinch points
controls:
Inspect all chain falls and slings prior to use. Tag and remove defective equipment.
Ensure rated tag is attached to any rigging including chains.
Identify load weight. Chose the right equipment for the job.
Verify all components capacities are properly marked.
Adequate hand protection should be worn when operating the chain fall.
Signal Person must ensure that all personnel are clear and have removed all rigging from equipment prior to signaling to operator to move rigging equipment. ONE SIGNALPERSON TO CALL CRANE AT A TIME.

hazards:
Slips, trips and falls
Falling objects
controls:
All holes must be covered before leaving the area.
Use the appropriate hole cover to protect the area below.
Covers should be labeled.
Covers should be checked and replaced as needed.

hazards:
Falling objects/Struck by
Electrical hazards
Pinch points
Lacerations
Slips, trips and falls
controls:
Before coring, sonar shall identify potential rebar, conduits, wires, etc. Look for and avoid additional finishes.
The coring machine will be inspected by its operator prior to each use. Only an authorized operator is to use the machine.
The coring machine is anchored to the deck to ensure that it does not move out of place.
The spotter and corer shall wear manufacturer-recommended PPE including ear plugs and goggles and full face shield.
A CAZ will be created under cores. A receptacle will be placed directly under the core to control any falling material.
There will be a spotter below the core to control the falling core. See Spotter's Responsibilities.
A wetvac will be used to remove spoils.

hazards:
Falling objects/Struck by
Slips, trips and falls
Pinch points
controls:
The spotter shall never leave the corer unattended.
The spotter must be in control of the CAZ.
The spotter shall stay in constant communication with the corer.
The spotter will be responsible to clean up excess water and debris during and after the core is drilled.
The spotter will be responsible for moving the receptacle as needed to collect additional cores.
The spotter will remove the red tape after completion of the task.

"Laser in Use" signs shall be posted within 50' of where Trimble or lasers are being used for layout.
Only trained user can operate the trimble.
Follow manufacture's safety recommendations for operating the Trimble.
Do not wear reflective vests when the Trimble laser is in use.
Signs shall be removed when the operations are completed.

hazards:
Dropped or Falling Objects
Slips, trips and falls
controls:
Evaluate floor completion -- cover any existing holes, or report holes to the [Customer]
Ensure there is proper access and egress to the deck.
Verify guardrail systems are complete including toe boards
Work area is clear of debris
Be cautious of other trades' inbeds
Make sure [Customer] has signed off deck before we access deck.

Schedule and conduct meeting with all affected parties.
Create CAZ with barriers and signage.
NFPA 70E trained, qualified workers shall wear ARC FLASH suits. Workers are responsible for inspecting suit for defects, burn marks, tearing and normal wear and tear. Workers shall have on nothing that is conductive.
Workers will use insulated gloves and tools while working near electrical panels.

Worker will turn the switch of the disconnect into an off position, LOTO the disconnect, loosen screws and pull the cover off.
The switch will be turned back on to test with a meter.
A meter will be installed to check the voltage output. The meter reading will then be documented.
The switch will then be turned off, cover put back on and secured into place. Document closure and securing of the panel.
Re-energize the panel.

Remove suit and place it in the storage bag for next use.
Remove signage and barriers so others working in the area know that they can enter.
Before removing any guardrail or barricade, prior written permission from [Customer] must be obtained.

The following actions will need to be completed before any work can be performed where fall protect will be required:
[Customer] Safety Manager will review the area where work is to take place and determine if a work plan and permit will be required.
All workers will be trained in fall protection.
Fall protective equipment will be inspected before each use.
The tie off points will be to a column, a beam or an approved anchor point that can withstand a minimum 5,000 lbs.
NOTE: Safety cables are not made to be a tie off point so DO NOT USE them as one.

Verify that barrels are tight and safe to move. Verify labeling on barrel to reflect product and SDS. Discuss hazards of working around fuel oil with affected employees. Have spill kit ready for any potential spills. Barrel cart will be used to move barrels.
[internalCustomer] to check valve rotation to fully closed.

task: Pressurize Piping with Air and Purge each outlet
controls: Confirm path of blow out is clear. Verify doors are closed. Communicate with each worker that valve is being opened.
PPM to check valve rotation to fully open. After system is energized, visual inspection to verify no leaks.

task: Pressurize piping with jet fuel and purge each outlet
controls: Employees working with jet fuel will wear additional PPE including rubber gloves. The hose used for purging shall be properly placed inside barrel so as not to come loose and should be monitored.
Calling environmental waste disposal company.

PPE REQUIRED: hardhats, ANSI-Z87 safety glasses, work boots, sleeved shirt, long pants, safety vest and task-specific gloves.
Appropriate PPE to protect worker from additional hazard exposure.
Perform stretch and flex exercises before starting any strenuous activity.

Review personnel-specific and task-specific hazards with crew.
Document worker acknowledgment of understanding of task and hazards.

task: Transport tools, materials, & equipment to the work area
hazards:
Dropped or falling objects
Sprains & strains
Cuts or lacerations
controls:
Do not overload materials.
Verify clear path to work area. Watch footing.
Ask for help when lifting heavy or awkward material.
Use proper lifting techniques and/or use mechanical means when available.
Wear gloves to protect from cuts or pinches.

Employees should drink four 8-ounce glasses of water, or a total of one quart per hour to stay hydrated throughout the day.
Employees should be trained on Heat Illness signs and symptoms and should report any concerns immediately.
Employees should be trained on [internalCustomer]'s HIPP.
Traffic control is to be provided by Certified Flaggers when exposed to public traffic.

hazards:
Cuts or Lacerations
Sprains & Strains
Slips, Trips and Falls
Exposure to dust
controls:
Use gloves to avoid cuts, punctures and lacerations.
Use proper lifting procedures when lifting heavy material.
Clean as you go.
Be aware of [internalCustomer]'s voluntary respiratory program.
Use Absorb Sweep when needed/allowed.
Keep material organized and stacked properly.

Have a fire watch during any cutting or welding of decks and it shall be maintained for at least a half hour after completion of welding or cutting operations to detect and extinguish possible smoldering fires.
This employee will safe off the area, remove or cover any flammable materials and carry a fire extinguisher while cutting or sparks are being generated.

A hot work permit must be submitted to [Customer] and posted after approval and during the work.
Use the appropriate shaded eye protection for the task. Use heat resistant gloves and any additional PPE as needed.
Have an appropriate fire extinguisher readily available. Have water spray bottles and fire blankets ready prior to the hot work.
Inspect fire extinguishers prior to use and ensure tags are current. Tag and remove any defective equipment.
Inspect all equipment before each use. Tag and remove any defective equipment.
Identify and protect all material from damage.
Report any fires to [Customer] immediately.
During hot work, a fire watch must be set up and maintained for at least 30 minutes after the work is completed.

Secure bottle(s) in place on cart
Secure cart from shifting, tipping over

task: Welding of galvanized or stainless material
hazards:
Burns
Eye Injury
Arc-flash
Electrical Shock
Fires
controls:
Create CAZ and post Hot Work Permit.
Use appropriate welding PPE. Maintain appropriate head protection.
Use weld screens when working around other workers.
Inspect your equipment before each use. Tag and remove any defected equipment from service.
A flint striker shall be used be used to light torch.
Wear a respirator (refer to our respirator program under separate cover)
At breaks, lunch and at end of day turn off gauges and protect the hoses.
Ensure adequate ventilation where needed.

task:
Welding
Soldering
Brazing
Heat gun
Cutting torch
Plasma Cutter
hazards:
Fire
Burns
Fumes
Injury to Self: Hand or Eye
Injury to others
controls:
Create CAZ and post Hot Work Permit.
Ensure the employee performing the hot work is trained in the specific type of hot work.
Use appropriate PPE. Maintain appropriate head protection.
Use weld screens when working around other workers.
A flint striker shall be used be used to light torch.
At breaks, lunch and at end of day turn off gauges and protect the hoses.
Ensure adequate ventilation where needed.

hazards:
Eye Injury
Flying debris
Hot sparks/Fires
Cuts/Punctures
Loss of control of grinder
controls:
Follow manufactures' recommendation for PPE.
Use face shield and glasses.
Have a fire extinguisher readily available. Have fire blankets and spray bottles readily available.
Provide a fire watch or similar protection to adjacent people and materials.
Inspect your grinder before each use. Tag and remove any defected equipment from service.
Ensure the grinder has both handles and that you are using them.
Use the appropriate guard for the appropriate task.

hazards:
Fire
Tipping over
Breaking of gauges
Release of pressurized gasses
controls:
For short-term storage (during a shift):
Turn off gauges
Secure the hoses from any damage

For long-term storage (at end of shift or when welding tanks shall not be used in 24 hours):
Remove gauges
Secure safety caps
If bottles are stored on cart, cart must have 30 minute fire barrier, or bottles must be separated by at least 20 feet and secured.
Storage should be in an area not exposed to any impact hazards.

hazards:
Flying debris and particles
Fire
Fumes, Vapors
controls:
Wear the appropriate PPE for the task.
All welding machines need to be turned off and cooled before fueling can begin.
Make sure there is proper ventilation.
Try to stand up wind when refueling.
Fire extinguished needs to be readily available during fueling.

Contact [Customer] to access and review job hazard material survey
In the case of asbestos: recognize, report and retreat. We do not work with asbestos material.
Take precautions for any other material according to the job hazard material survey
Review necessary SDSs with the crew
Wear proper PPE
Provide training for specific hazards

Prepare for hazards for specific system
Implement the COHE where necessary.

Coordinator with [Customer].
LOTO in place. Secure all pipe termination against displacement.
Atmospheric monitoring.
Proper ventilation.

Shut off fixtures upstream or install plug.
Proper PPE for any possible exposure. Immunizations up to date.
LOTO in place. Secure all pipe termination against displacement.
Have spill bucket in place. Clean any spills immediately.

hazards:
Water Spills
Slips, Trips and Falls
Water burns
controls:
Isolate and confirm valves.
LOTO in place. Secure all pipe termination against displacement.
Have spill bucket in place. Clean any spills immediately.

hazards:
Caught Between
Struck By
Dropped or Falling Objects
controls:
While stocking or moving pallets make sure that you know your surroundings and you don't put yourself in a pinch point.
Try to push rather than pull.
Make sure that wheels are chalked or locked when done.
Do not be behind a load -- maintain eye contact with operator.
Ensure all pallets are rated for the intended load and are not over loaded.
Always follow manufacture's stocking requirements.
Do not stock more than 5 pallets high or exceed overall height of 20 feet.

hazards:
Struck By
Caught between/Pinch
Sprains & Strains
controls:
Watch your hands, legs, arms and feet while loading and unloading material.
When offloading material, workers will ensure that they use proper lifting techniques which include asking for help or using mechanical means to lift heavy material.
If a worker is required to climb on top of the load which exposes him to a potential fall of greater than 6 feet, then full fall protections procedures will be followed.
Employee shall try to utilize tools available to them to transport material. If possible, use a dolly, cart, wagon or a pallet using a forklift. Avoid moving material by hand if possible.

All crew members will participate in a daily stretch and flex.
Plan ahead before lifting. Know where you are going with your load. Don't make awkward movements. Clear a path, and if lifting something with another person, make sure both of you agree on the plan.
Lift close to your body. Make sure you have a firm hold on the object you are lifting, and keep it balanced close to your body.
Feet shoulder width apart. Keep both feet about shoulder width apart and take short steps.
Bend your knees and keep your back straight. Focus on keeping you spine straight. Raise and lower to the ground by bending your knees.
Tighten your stomach muscles. Tightening your abdominal muscles will hold your back in a good lifting position and will help prevent excessive force on the spine.
Lift with your legs. Your legs are many times stronger than your back muscles-let your strength work in your favor. Again, lower to the ground by bending your knees, not your back.
If you're straining, get help. If an object is too heavy, or awkward in shape, get someone to help you lift it.
Never bend your back to pick something up. Hold the object close to your body. Don't twist or bend. Face in the direction you are walking. If you need to turn, stop, turn in small steps, and then continue walking. Keep your eyes up which will help you maintain a better position of the spine.
Create controlled access zone using danger tape and/or signs.

Two crew members shall remove the barrier to gain access.
Workers shall ensure fall protection system is in place and worn properly.
Workers shall use the buddy system when removing the barrier. Crew members shall keep each other aware of how close they are to the edge.

task: Receive material and hand off to other crew members outside of CAZ
hazards:
Caught Between
Struck By
Cuts and lacerations
Pinch points
controls:
Each member shall have good communication where the load will be placed and then moved out of the loading bay.
Stay back away from the load while pushing it off the bay.
Ensure proper PPE including gloves and body positioning.

Two crew members shall replace the barrier.
Workers shall ensure fall protection system is in place and worn properly.
Workers shall use the buddy system when replacing the barrier. Crew members shall keep each other aware of how close they are to the edge.
In the case of cable barrier, ensure maximum deflection of 6 inches.
Only when barrier is properly restored, workers can disconnect from anchor point and remove controlled access zone

hazards:
Contact with (eyes, skin, inhalation, splash, accidental release)
Burns
Sprains & strain
controls: Decontamination set up and equipment shall be available in the case of an emergency.

hazards:
Contact with (eyes, skin, inhalation, splash, accidental release)
Burns
Sprains & strain
controls:
Chemical will be added one gallon at a time.
Workers shall take their time to avoid spills and contact with chemicals.
Wear appropriate PPE for the task.

task: Compact tank pad to sub grade
controls:
Wear proper over-shoe guards
Monitor and manage repetitive motion activities
Wear leather gloves to protect hands
Communicate with other workers in the area

hazards:
Slips, trips and falls
Cave-ins and water accumulation
Ladder Collapse/fall
Falling objects
Struck by
controls:
Competent person performs daily inspection.
Shore any excavation 5' feet or deeper or as conditions require
In trenches more than 4' deep, set up and secure a ladder within 25 ft of each worker in the excavation.
Fall protection required when falls of 6' or greater is possible.

task: Layout for placement of dead man and set dead man
hazards:
Caught Between
Struck By
Slips, trips and falls
controls:
Proper rigging by a certified rigger and signal man.
Use tag lines to control the load as it comes off the trailer.
After setting the dead man, chalk to prevent roll over.
Do not get under a suspended load

hazards:
Falling or Shifting loads
Uncontroled load
Tipping Over
Rigging failure
Struck by
Crushing/Pinch Points
controls:
Tank lift plan approved by [internalCustomer] and [Customer].
Inspect all rigging equipment before use.
Use tag line.
Only trained and experience riggers will rig up loads.

Use fall protection when a fall of 6' or greater is possible
Watch crane hook
Keep hands out of pinch points
Wear appropriate hand protection
Communication and spotting as needed for disconnection of straps

task: Perform testing procedures for tank quality -- release air pressure.
controls:
Follow the COHE program when appropriate.
Verify that all valves and bolts are tight.
Spray with a soap and water mixture to see if there are any leeks.
Set a CAZ prior to pressure testing. Communicate with necessary personnel prior to pressure testing.
Wear the appropriate eye protection.

hazards:
Lacerations to hands
Caught between
Pinch Points
Eye injury
controls:
Proper use of ladder, 3-point contact while climbing
Use fall protection when fall of 6' or greater is possible.
Wear appropriate hand protection.
Wear appropriate eye protection.
Keep your hands out of pinch points.

task: Backfill around the base and any void areas underneath
hazards:
Struck by
Caught between /Pinch Points
Repetitive motion
Fugitive dust
controls:
Use the appropriate foot, hand and eye protection.
Use leather gloves if running the compactor.
Use administrative controls for repetitive motion.

task: Isolate and drain fuel line that will be welded on
hazards:
Slips and falls
Fumes and vapors
Contact with and spills
controls:
The lines will be shut down at both ends and isolated.
The line will then be cracked and drained of fuel oil.
Excess fuel will be removed from the area and drips and puddles will be wiped up.

task: Hook up nitrogen purge to the line that will be welded on
controls:
Check nitrogen regulator before operating nitrogen.
Purge ports will be hooked up to both ends.
Allowing a constant purge while welding.
Wear appropriate PPE for the task.

task: Weld fittings and bypass to fuel line
hazards:
Arc
Bright Light
Explosions
Flash Burns
Injury to Self
Chemical Exposure
Fumes
controls:
Set up weld screens to shield passers-by from weld glare
Wear properly tinted welding lenses.
Be sure to have your HOT WORK PERMIT in place prior to starting work. Follow hot work procedures.
Assess work area to make sure that there are no flammable materials stored. Have a fire extinguisher close by.
Wear the proper welding PPE. Set up barrier tape around weld area to prevent accidental contact with hot pipe welds.
Welders to maintain their distance from welding fumes. Set up ventilation fans or smoke hogs to remove/control welding fumes.

task: Adjusting and ramping up air speeds for testing
hazards:
Fugitive dust
Caught by/Pinch points
Struck by
controls:
Equipment will be running during this process. Speeds will be ramped up all the way to ensure that everything is working correctly.
Watch for excessive vibration, noise or impropper movement before ramping up.
Ensure that all moving parts are protected such as pulleys, belts, fan blades

task: Opening door to increase air flow
hazards:
Struck by
Caught between
Fugitive dust
Sucked inside
controls:
This task may need to happen to get max air flow through the system.
CAZ will be created to ensure no one gets hurt or injured during this operation.

task: Verify components are secure and in place
controls:
Workers will enter the units to make sure all of the internal components are properly fastened and secured.
This task shall be done before unit is started and after it has been shut down to make sure nothing has come loose and is still secure.

Confirm insulation, labeling, gauges, thermometers, TE Wells, and valves are complete.
Verify no heat sensitive materials are touching bare pipe or components.
Pressure reliefs are installed and piped to approved location.
Close and tag out all steam isolation valves to keep steam in the energized section that will be monitored during energization.

task: Remove Lock-out/Tag-out from main valve in Central Utility Plant
hazards:
Burns
Dropped or Falling Objects
Sprains & Strains
controls: Set up ladder to access main steam valve, remove LOTO and slowly crack valve to introduce steam to building.

task: Open branch line valves to allow steam through other controlled areas of hospital.
controls: Slowly crack valves to introduce steam & Monitor steam as it enters the piping system by walking and visually inspecting all piping.

Identify all leaks with flags, if necessary barricade the area below the leak to prevent anyone from walking under the leak.
If possible isolate the leak or de-energize the system, relieve any residual pressure before repairing leaks.

A job walk will be preformed verifying every gas valve in all buildings are closed and all POC's are capped or connected.
All gas lines will be visually inspected verifying they are complete and no disruption or damage has occurred.
Lines will be soaped to verify no leaks.
LOTO all effected gas valves.
All effected exterior main shutoff valves will be visually inspected to verify they are closed prior to inducing gas to the main line.
Prior to gas introducing into each building, a secondary verification walk will be done to verify nothing has compromised the system. During that walk we will verify all other trades are out of area.
We will verify no "HOT WORK" or sparks of any kind are in the area.
Purge the system in a vented area.
Signs will be placed where necessary reading "DO NOT OPEN--GAS PURGING" and red tape will be used to barricade the effected area. [internalCustomer] to verify with the electrician that equipment is de-energized.

task: Area set up confirm fire extinguishers are working and up to date
controls: Post warning signage and caution tape. Review procedure and area borers with GC for coordinating with other trades post monitor with extinguisher.

task: Confirm gas clock valves are closed
hazards: Loss of Natural Gas into rooms: Cafe Kitchen, Boiler Room, etc.
controls: [internalCustomer] to check valve rotation to fully closed.

task: Evacuate air and replace with natural gas
controls: Confirm Multi-Gas sensor is fully charged. Confirm cafe, kitchen and energy center air supply and exhaust are operational. Post monitor to watch for other trades entering or creating sparks. The use of fans may be necessary.

task: After gas is on, recheck all gas valves and outlets
hazards: Loss of Natural Gas into rooms: Cafe Kitchen, Boiler Room, etc.
controls: Walk all gas valves to insure that gas is off/or pilot is lit.
After blind flange is installed, soap all areas to assure that there are no leaks

task: Connect gas piping to building supply
controls: Assure that all connections are tight before gas is turned on

task: Remove Lock Out of Gas Sub Meter, Open Gas Valves
controls: Soap all connections

task: Set up fans to ventilate area
controls: Establish Good ventilation in effected area.

task: Purge air from the gas line with natural gas. At first sign of odor shut off valve and secure appliance. Test connection.
controls: Fire extinguisher on site. Warn other trades in area. Remove any ignition sources. Establish good ventilation in the area. Soap all connections to detect leaks.

All workers will be certified and have the proper training to be purging and brazing on med gas lines.
A fan will be set up to have a continuous draft of fresh air.
Monitoring equipment will be available while purging is done.

task:
Isolate piping section for testing.
Install hydro and/or test equipment
hazards:
Leaks & Joint Failures
Damage to Piping
Laceration
Struck by
Contusions
controls:
Verify all joints are tightened.
Verify all fittings and pipe sections are welded.
Cover sensitive equipment at high risk points.
Isolate test section with locks and tags.
Do not use LOTO hardware for testing purposes.

hazards:
Joint Failures
Release of Air, Nitrogen or water
Leaks & Spills
controls:
Verify all joints are tightened.
Install relief valves after hydro test is complete.
Open fittings slowly to vent pressure.
Use hoses to direct vent discharges to nearest drain.
Conduct a second check of all vents closed prior to pressurization.

hazards:
Pressure release
Property damage
Lacerations
Burns
Struck by
controls:
Slowly pressurize system in steps and inspect system each step.
Have enough manpower along piping to quickly identify problems.
Use hoses to direct vent discharges to nearest drain.

hazards:
Leaving pressurized sections of pipe
Leaks & Spills
controls:
Open each vent or drain valve to depressurize complete system.
Use hoses to direct vent discharges to nearest drain. Cover sensitive equipment at high risk points.

Check vents/drains closed before releasing system to [Customer].
All vent/drain valves are plugged before passification

Schedule off hours.
Give notification.

task: Using air compressor to pressurize waste and vent systems
controls:
Wear the appropriate PPE for the task.
Only testing to 5 PSI
Use a GFCI to plug into walls
Testing equipment (air compressors/hydrostatic pump) should be checked daily to ensure good working order.
Look for leaks and loose fittings.
Compressors and pump will be used to fill up the piping systems.
Be sure that hose connections are fully locked and whip checks are in place to ensure a good fit and avoid any accidental blow offs and spillage.

Check the Testing Matrix for the proper test pressure for the system.
Place signage in area which states [internalCustomer] is testing at a certain pressure with a contact phone number on it.
Do not stand in front of the end of any pipe while testing.
When testing with Air - Pressurize the system to 40 psi. Check gauge for drop in pressure then walk system to check for leaks.
After thorough walk, pressurize system up to 100 PSI with air. Then walk the system again and check for leaks.
When testing with Water - Pressurize system up to the test pressure on the Pressure Matrix for that specific system with water. Then walk the system again and check for leaks.
Keep an emergency spill kit nearby to ensure a quick clean up process in the event of a water spill.
Our spill kits include a spill buggy, shop vac, cotton rags, absorbent materials and push broom.
DEPRESSURIZE THE SYSTEM prior to making ANY repairs.
DEPRESSURIZE THE SYSTEM when complete with test.

Verify the [Customer] policy on ladders.
Choose the right ladder for the job. Do not overreach on any ladder.
Inspect ladder for any defects or problems. Verify the stickers are legible. Verify the monthly inspection sticker is current.
Make sure that ladder is properly secured at top and bottom and extends at least 3 feet above the landing.
Maintain proper footing when descending and ascending ladder using Belt-Buckle Rule (stay in the center of the ladder) and 3 points of contact.
Utilize fall protection when working within 6 feet of any opening or the edge of the building.
The height you are working at on the ladder needs to be taken into consideration when calculating the distance from the leading edge.

Verify the [Customer] policy on ladders.
Choose the right ladder for the job. Do not overreach on any ladder.
Inspect all ladders for any defects or damage. Verify the stickers are legible. Verify the monthly inspection sticker is current.
Ensure ladder is properly secured from displacement.
Maintain proper footing when descending and ascending ladder using Belt-Buckle Rule (stay in the center of the ladder) and 3 points of contact.
Utilize fall protection when working within 6 feet of any opening or the edge of the building.
The height you are working at on the ladder needs to be taken into consideration when calculating the distance from the leading edge.

Verify the [Customer] policy on ladders.
Choose the right ladder for the job. Do not overreach on any ladder. Do not walk a ladder while working from it.
Inspect all ladders for any defects or damage. Verify the stickers are legible. Verify the monthly inspection sticker is current.
Ensure ladder is properly secured from displacement. Ladder must be fully opened and locked.
Do not straddle an A-Frame ladder. Do not use the top two steps.
Maintain proper footing when descending and ascending ladder using Belt-Buckle Rule (stay in the center of the ladder) and 3 points of contact.
Utilize fall protection when working within 6 feet of any opening or the edge of the building.
The height you are working at on the ladder needs to be taken into consideration when calculating the distance from the leading edge.

Perform and document equipment inspection prior to each use. All manufacturer's safety labels must be legible. Red tag and remove defective equipment.
All operators shall be trained and authorized.
Operate equipment per manufacturer's suggested safety requirements.
Ensure operating paths are clear and unobstructed.
Make visual contact with operator before approaching the equipment or crossing its path.

Ensure proper agency has located and marked all utility lines before work begins.
Attempt to have utility lines shut-off or de-energized by appropriate agencies, if possible.
Keep equipment and personnel away from utility lines, when possible.
Keep at least 20 feet from overhead power lines.

All power tools will have manufacturers' safety guards properly in place.
Proper PPE will be worn at all time including goggles and face shield if required.
Tools will be inspected daily for damage before use. Tag and remove defective equipment from use.
While cutting, make sure all body parts are away from the cutting surface. Always cut away from the body.

Do not use electrical cords with cuts, worn insulation, or visible conductors or field repairs (electrical tape).
Use cords rated for hard or extra-hard usage. Use factory-assembled cord sets. Do not use rubber molded (flat) cords.
Extension cord repairs will be performed by a qualified electrician.
Field repairs (electrical tape) fixes are prohibited.
Extension cords will be inspected daily; extension cords will be rolled up at the end of the shift.
All circuits shall be GFCI protected.
Two electrical cords cannot be used together unless approved by the manufacturer. Do not connect multiple devices in a linear fashion (daisy chain).
Electrical cords must be protected from traffic, sharp edges and/or pinch points.

Shut off machine
Equipment shall be cold before refueling
Fuel in spill area
All equipment to have fire suppression.

hazards:
Electrocution or Shock
Back strain
Injury to Self: Eye, Face
Disfigurement and lacerations
Slips, Trips, & Falls
controls:
Use proper lifting techniques.
Face shield over safety glasses required when operating the chop saw.
Wear appropriate hand protection according manufacturer's requirements.
Do not reach over or around the saw during cutting.
Hearing protection required for over 85 dB.
Maintain a clean work area. Place scrap pieces in trash or bucket.
Ensure the blade is the proper size and RPM for the saw.

hazards:
Struck by
Electrical hazards
Roll over
Ejection
Drowning
Caught between
controls:
Operator must be authorized by [internalCustomer] Mechanical.
Inspect and document the equipment prior to each use.
The safety zone is 15 feet from the extended boom.
Authorized personnel may enter the safety zone as long as they remain in the peripheral view of the operator and do not turn their back on the boom.
Do not allow bystanders or spotters to get between stationary object and the equipment.
Do not operate within 20 ft of energized, overhead electrical lines.
Do not operate on slopes greater than the equipment specifications allow.
Seat belts must be worn at all times when operating the equipment. If working around water, seat belt is not required, but a PFD is.
Riders are not allowed in buckets or on side steps.

hazards:
Struck by
Electrical hazards
Roll over
Ejection
Drowning
Caught between
controls:
Operator must have a certification within 3 years of training and be authorized by [internalCustomer] Mechanical.
Inspect and document the equipment prior to each use.
Use a CAZ for loading and unloading of material.
Use a spotter where necessary.
Do not allow bystanders or spotters to get between stationary object and the equipment.
Do not operate within 20 ft of energized, overhead electrical lines.
Do not operate on slopes greater than the equipment specifications allow.
Seat belts must be worn at all times when operating the equipment. If working around water, seat belt is not required, but a PFD is.
Riders are not allowed unless there is a seat and seat belt.
Honk your horn at blind corners.
Always maintain your load up hill.
Secure load when necessary.

hazards:
Tip overs
Falls
Electrocution
Pinch points
controls:
Employee needs to be trained and have a current certificate to operate the lift.
Inspect and document equipment prior to each use.
Scissor lift will be used per manufactures recommendations.
Do not operate the lift without the owner's manual present and legible.
Enter and exit the lift properly using the steps on the lift.
Watch for pinch points when operating the lift.
Do not run over electrical cords.
Do not exceed the capacity rating of the scissor lift.
Do not use the scissor lift as a material hoist.
Keep the floor clean at all times.
Use a spotter when necessary.
Be aware of your surroundings and overhead electrical hazards.
Do not move lift while in elevated position.

task: Gaining elevation from a scissor lift at heights using platform
controls:
PERMISSION REQUIRED.
If you must gain height from the scissor lift, contact [Customer] and/or the safety department in order to develop a proper written plan.
When gaining elevation, 100% tie off is required.

PERMISSION REQUIRED.
If you must exit a scissor lift while elevated to reach a working platform, you must contact [Customer] and/or the safety department to develop a proper written plan.
100% tie off required when exiting the scissor lift at height.

hazards:
Crushing
Electrocution
Dropped or Falling Objects
Tip Overs
controls:
Employee needs to be trained and have a current certificate to operate the lift.
Inspect and document equipment prior to each use.
Aerial lift will be used per manufactures' recommendations.
Do not operate the lift without the owner's manual present and legible.
Enter and exit the lift properly using the steps on the lift.
Watch for pinch points when operating the lift.
Do not run over electrical cords.
Do not exceed the capacity rating of the aerial lift.
Do not use the aerial lift as a material hoist.
Keep the floor clean at all times.
Use a spotter when necessary.
Be aware of your surroundings and overhead electrical hazards.
Do not move lift while in elevated position.

hazards:
Obstructed view
Caught in between
Crushed By
Falling
Machine rollover
Electrocution
controls:
Ensure that the operator's view is unobstructed when in raised or lowered positions and when moving in any direction.
Employees do not place body parts outside of the basket or near pinch points on the machine.
Do not allow workers to stand or walk under the elevated portion of the machine.
All workers in the basket must be 100% tied off and attached to the designated anchorage point.
Ensure the use of outriggers if machine is equipped.
Ensure the deadman on the floor of the boom lift is unobstructed.
Be aware of your surroundings and overhead electrical hazards.

task: Gaining elevation from an aerial lift at heights using platform
controls:
PERMISSION REQUIRED.
If you must gain height from the scissor lift, contact [Customer] and/or the safety department in order to develop a proper written plan.
When gaining elevation, 100% tie off is required.

Keep hands away from socket while using the impact wrench.
Wear gloves at all time on site.
Check impact wrench for any defects (cords, cracks).

hazards:
electric shock
pinch points
Dismemberment
lacerations
Crush
slip, trip and fall
Walking on Walking surfaces
Injuring others
controls:
Inspect all tools and equipment before each use For:
1. Bad electrical cords and plugs
2. Ensure all guards are in place and working
3. Look for any missing or damaged parts
Establish a controlled access zone
Wear manufacture required PPE
Keep material and tools organized
Housekeeping - keep area clean and keep clean as you go

Request the IH report/environmental inspection from Owner regarding the soil and possible contaminates. Follow recommendations of either report.
Call Dig Alert or 811 for public utility location.
Meet with [Customer] or Owner to identify existing utilities on private property.
When relying on an as-built, dig with great caution and expect changes from the as-built.

Only trained and authorized workers are allowed to rig and load.
Only trained and authorized workers are allowed to signal during the lift.
Create a CAZ.
Inspect all rigging equipment prior to each use. Tag and remove any defective equipment.
Ensure tag lines are connected to the load
Stand clear at all times from a suspended load or swing radius of counterweights.
Control rotation of load with multiple tag lines.

When rigging off a forklift, secure the load to the back rest, not the forks.
When rigging off an excavator, secure the load to the rigging eye.
Make sure the load capacity of the equipment is sufficient for the load.

Competent person must check soil conditions and take necessary precautions when circumstances present potential hazards.
Test the soil to determine if it is class A, B or C.
 A trench/excavation inspection report will be filled out prior to any shift and/or after any change in conditions.

Mark or stake location at least 2 feet to each side of located utility without damaging utility.
Hand dig to the side of the located utility until the approximate depth has been reached.
Dig towards the utility without damaging the utility's protective casing (conduit, insulation or concrete cover).
Dig along the path of the direction of the utility and clean spoils out without disturbing utility until it is completely exposed and visually recognizable.
Continue this process until you have uncovered at a minimum 2 feet from where any damage from hand tools or mechanical equipment being used can harm utility.
Excavation plan shall be approved by a registered engineer.

hazards:
Utility Strike
Struck by
Cave in
controls:
Fill out and complete dig permit prior to any excavation including locating underground utilities.
Set up a CAZ and remove any non-essential personnel.
A competent person shall be present while excavation taking place.
Utilize spotter when digging in an uncontrolled area. Utilize hand signals/radios to communicate between operator and surrounding crew.
Only authorized operators can operate equipment.
Pay attention to surroundings and any obstructions that may be present.
Inspect and document all equipment prior to use.
Set back spoils at least 2 feet from trench.

Rotate workers on repetitive motion tasks.
Stretch and flex before and during repetitive motion tasks.
task specific training for tasks/use the right tool for the job.
Do not enter a trench that is not properly protected.
Ensure adequate access/egress is provided.
Ensure proper PPE for the task.

task:
Protective systems for trenching
Benching or sloping
controls:
C Class soils shall not be benched.
When sloping or benching is used as a protective system, the sloping or benching will be in accordance with Cal/OSHA requirements.
Slope in accordance with the appropriate soil classification.
If there is more than one bench, the bottom bench must be at least 8 feet wide.

task: Protective systems for trenching and shoring
controls:
Install shoring when trench is five feet deep or as conditions require.
Install the shoring system and components in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendation and tabulated data.
Do not enter an unprotected excavation to install shoring.
Make sure the excavation is no deeper than 18 inches below the base of the shoring system.

hazards:
Crushed by
Struck by
Caught between/Pinch
Rigging failure
Fall
controls:
Choose the appropriate rigging for the job
Inspect rigging before each use.
Qualified person shall rig the material
No workers shall enter the trench without shoring properly in place. Do not be under a suspended load.
Only authorized operators shall operate equipment.
Workers/Spotters shall maintain fall protection if falls of greater than 6 feet are possible.
Workers/Spotters must maintain line-of-sight communication with operators.

Inspect the excavation, adjacent areas, and all protective systems before each shift and after conditions change.
Correct any unsafe conditions prior to workers entering the trench.
Check to see if ground water has accumulated.

In trenches more than 4 feet deep, set up ladders within 25 feet of each work area.
Tie-off the top of the ladder and extend the side rails 36 inches above the landing.
Set up two ladders for every 25 feet for access/egress.
Inspect ladders daily.

task: Working around or in excavation or trenching
hazards:
Falls
Workers exposed to heavy equipment
Cave ins
Engulfment
controls:
Guard-rails or PFAS to be provided on any fall exposure of 6 feet or more.
Back-up alarms or spotter to be used at all times.
Always be in the line of sight of the operator and 15 feet back from moving parts.
Limit amount of workers where equipment working.
Establish safe zone approximately 1:1 from bottom of trench. No vehicles or equipment shall be in this area.
Eliminate any surcharge to the adjacent area of the trench or excavation

task: Housekeeping near a trench or excavation
hazards:
Falling objects
Cave ins
Slips, trips and falls
controls:
Establish safe zone approximately 1:1 from bottom of trench. No vehicles or equipment shall be in this area.
Eliminate any surcharge to the adjacent area of the trench or excavation.
Material shall be maintained to avoid unexpected movement.

Provide warning signage and barricades when public is exposed to open excavation or trench.
All trenches or excavation need to be backfilled (if possible) or barricaded when unattended.

If a fall of 6 feet or greater is possible, utilize fall protection.
Utilize proper PPE for concrete work including rubber gloves and eye protection.
Select a clear, open space that allows for adequate equipment operation.
Do not park truck too close to any open excavation.
Utilize a spotter during truck placement to recognize any obstructions.

hazards:
Falls
Sprains and strains
Cave in
Slips, trips and falls
controls:
If a fall of 6 feet or greater is possible, utilize fall protection.
No workers allowed in the trench during backfill operations.
Rotate workers on repetitive motion tasks.
Stretch and flex before and during repetitive motion tasks.
Only authorized operators may operate equipment.
Wear gloves when using shovel.

hazards:
Heavy equipment crush
Struck by
Utility strike
Caught between
controls: Refer to excavation JHA

task: Compact trench bottom and base with sand
hazards:
Cave-ins
Open trench
Falls
Sprains and strains
controls:
Safe off work area with delineators or barricades.
Rotate workers on repetitive motion tasks.
Stretch and flex before and during repetitive motion tasks.
Use the appropriate PPE for a mechanical compactor -- foot protection and gloves when using shovel/compactor.
Remove trench shield in the same manner that it was installed.

hazards:
Struck by
Caught in between
Falls
Trench failure due to equipment weight
controls:
Only trained personnel in the CAZ during setting of the shield.
Workers shall be tied off is exposed to a fall of 6 feet or more.
Only authorized operators to operate equipment.
Equipment should maintain a 10 foot distance from the excavation.

hazards:
Struck by
Caught in between
Pinch points
Falls
controls:
Set interceptor in the excavation with rated pick plan. Refer to pick plan.
Create CAZ and remove unnecessary personnel.
Workers exposed to a fall of 6 feet or more shall use fall protection.

Keep all equipment at least 10 feet from the excavation.
Workers exposed to a fall of 6 feet or more shall use fall protection.
Pour the slurry off a concrete truck up to four feet from the top of the excavation.
Let the slurry set up.

hazards:
Falls
Sprains and strains
Cave in
Slips, trips and falls
controls:
If a fall of 6 feet or greater is possible, utilize fall protection.
No workers allowed in the trench during backfill operations.
Rotate workers on repetitive motion tasks.
Stretch and flex before and during repetitive motion tasks.
Only authorized operators may operate equipment.
Wear gloves when using shovel.

task: Excavate adjacent to existing sewer and at Points of Connection
hazards:
Heavy equipment crush
Struck by
Utility strike
Caught between
controls:
Refer to excavation JHA
Install protective trench system if depth requires it.

task: Compact trench bottom and base with sand
hazards:
Cave-ins
Open trench
Falls
Sprains and strains
controls:
Safe off work area with delineators or barricades.
Rotate workers on repetitive motion tasks.
Stretch and flex before and during repetitive motion tasks.
Use the appropriate PPE for a mechanical compactor -- foot protection and gloves when using shovel/compactor.

task: Make tie-ins from new sewer to existing
hazards:
Injury to Self: Eyes, Hands
Biohazards
controls:
Wear proper PPE for the task.
Use a face shield when running cut-off saw.

hazards:
Falls
Sprains and strains
Cave in
Slips, trips and falls
controls:
Be aware of surroundings,
Maintain eye contact with operator,
Wear appropriate PPE for the task. .

hazards:
Conflicts with other trades
Slips, trips and falls
Lacerations
controls:
Wear appropriate PPE for the task including cut-resistant gloves
It is recommended that workers wear long sleeve shirts to avoid cuts from tie-wire.
Coordinate activities with other trades.
Watch your step -- step on the rebar crosses
Complete work before lower mat of rebar is installed.
Install supports only as high as the lower mat until pipe is installed.
Watch for overhead loads.

task: Setting up Fusin Machine for PE Piping
controls:
Know that heating plates are HOT and will burn if touched.
Keep cords out of wet areas, puddles and sharp edges. Raise cords up in high traffic areas.
Wear gloves to protect your hands.
Check cords for any damage such as breaks, cuts broken ends and ground prong.

hazards:
Sprains and Strains
Lacerations
Dropped or Falling Objects
Crushed Body Parts
Slips, Trips, & Falls
Electrocution and/or Shocks
Struck by
Caught between
controls:
Use proper lifting technique. Don't lift more than 50 lbs. If material is more than 50 lbs. or awkward, get help or use mechanical means.
Create a CAZ if material or tools have a potential of falling on others in the area.
Tether tools that have a potential to fall.
For overhead piping, ensure the pipe is secured to the scissor lift.
For in-wall piping, ensure the pipe is properly strapped, riser clams tight.
Proper PPE should be worn to protect you from hazards associated with the task.
Maintain material storage 6' from edge of an opening or the edge of the building.
Protect other trades' products from trade damage.
Clean as you go.

task: Cut pipe and tubing to length
controls:
Inspect all tools before each use.
Unplug tool when not in use and before replacing blades.
Wear appropriate hand protection according to manufacture's recommendations for the cutting tool being used.
Deburr edges after cuts.
When cutting in the air, a CAZ should be created.
When cutting pipe on the ground, it should be secured in a vise.
Clean as you go.

task: Threading with a pipe threading machine
hazards:
Equipment Binding, Pinch Points
Flying Debris
Cuts or Lacerations
Slips, trips and falls
controls:
Inspect threading equipment before each use.
Keep fingers clear of pipe jaws when securing work piece.
Use cutting oil for all threading operations.
Operators stand to one side of cutting and threading head in case head spins or binds.
Always use foot pedal to operate threading equipment.
Safety goggles and face shield required when using threading machine.
Make sure there is NO loose clothing or cuffs on long sleeves shirts to get caught in moving parts.
Follow manufacture's recommendations for hand protection.
Clean up oil with rags and petroleum absorbents such as Oil-Dry.
Protect ground from oil splatter to protect from slips, trips and falls.
Area should be cleared of non-essential personnel.

Warn other trades in area.
Identify and isolate any possible ignition sources in the area.
Establish good ventilation.
Protect floors and walls from droppings.
Store Glue/Primer cans in flammable cabinet when not in use.
Employees shall be trained in the products they will be using. Review SDS before use.
Wear appropriate PPE as specified in the SDS.
Dispose empty cans as described by the SDS.

task: Installation No Hub Cast Iron Pipe
hazards:
Falling objects
Pinch points
Sprains and strains
Lacerations
controls:
Cast iron pipe will be safely lifted and put into hangers using proper lifting procedures.
A CAZ should be created below pipe being lifted.
When installing heavy pipe, use assistance or mechanical means to lift.
When using a scissor lift to lift heavy pipe, use pipe stands that continue to the floor of the scissor lift.
When using a chain fall to lift heavy pipe, you must have a rated anchor point and a rated connection between chain fall and anchor point. The chain fall must have the lifting capacity for the material being lifted.
When using snap cutters, always cut away from any opening and secure smaller pieces.
Keep body parts out of potential pinch points.
No Hub Couplings will be installed on the ends of each pipe by securely seating both ends of the pipe in the coupling.
Do not tighten any bands by holding them in your hand without any pipe of fittings.
All the bands of the coupling are individually tightened and torqued to 60-80 Ft. Lbs. to ensure the joint will hold.

hazards:
Falling objects
Pinch points
Sprains and strains
Lacerations
Burns
Eye hazards
Fires
controls:
Copper pipe will be safely lifted and put into hangers using proper lifting procedures.
A CAZ should be created below pipe being lifted.
When installing heavy pipe, use assistance or mechanical means to lift.
When using a scissor lift to lift pipe, use brackets appropriate for the pipe being lifted.
Use a pipe stand if necessary for weight of load.
When using a chain fall to lift pipe, you must have a rated anchor point and a rated connection between chain fall and anchor point. The chain fall must have the lifting capacity for the material being lifted.
Keep body parts out of potential pinch points.
A Hot Work Permit will be requested and posted prior to soldering or brazing.
After pipe is secured in hangers, press, solder or braze pipe into its final position.

hazards:
Falling objects
Pinch points
Sprains and strains
Lacerations
Burns/Fires
Accidental gas release
Eye hazards
controls:
Schedule 40 pipe will be safely lifted and put into hangers using proper lifting procedures.
A CAZ should be created below pipe being lifted.
When installing heavy pipe, use assistance or mechanical means to lift.
When using a scissor lift to lift pipe, use brackets appropriate for the pipe being lifted.
Use a pipe stand if necessary for weight of load.
When using a chain fall to lift pipe, you must have a rated anchor point and a rated connection between chain fall and anchor point. The chain fall must have the lifting capacity for the material being lifted.
Keep body parts out of potential pinch points
After the pipe is secured in hanger, the pipe and fitting will be secured to together in its final position.
A Hot Work Permit will be requested and posted prior to welding.
The pipe will be welded together using approved procedures by approved welders.
Once the system is completely installed, the system will be tested.
Lock Out/Tag Out will be preformed at the gas meter once turned on by the gas company to ensure the system is not energized.

hazards:
Falling objects
Pinch points
Sprains and strains
Lacerations
controls:
Gutter drain piping will be installed using a boom lift
Boom lift will be inspected before each use.
Follow manufacture's operating instructions.
The boom lift operator will be trained and authorized to operate the boom lift.
Ensure the pipe is secured from falling at all times.
Keep body parts out of potential pinch points.
A CAZ will be created before the lift is extended.
Appropriate fall protection will be used.

hazards:
Slips, trips and falls
Falling material
Pinch points
controls:
Materials to be stored in an area not to interfere with our work or others'.
Pipe will be stored on dunnage with chocks or stored on pipe racks.
Keep material organized when not in use.
Clean as you go.
Keep body parts out of potential pinch points.

task: Installation of in-wall cans and sleeves
hazards:
Slips, trips and falls
Pinch points
Lacerations
controls:
100% fall protection is required when a fall of 6' or greater is possible.
A positioning device cannot be used for climbing.

task: Punch and dimple decking for strapping
hazards:
Lacerations
Protruding objects
Flying particles & debris
controls:
Wear cut-resistant gloves when working with hanger materials.
Use vise to hold materials during cutting.
File sharp edges of strut.
Paint to identify ends of straps.
Use proper eye protection while punching metal decking.

hazards:
Pinch points
Falling objects
Mechanical failure
Sprains & strains
controls:
Keep hands out of mechanical gears and moving parts.
Lock wheels to avoid machine from moving while in use.
Once material is on surface secure it by means and methods (clamps or straps).
Inspect hoisting cable for bird caging, damaged wires, cracks in structure and welds.
Use of team work while moving, unloading, setting up or making adjustments.

task: Install ceiling wires using powder actuated tools
hazards:
Flying particles or debris
Charged strips: spent shot strips
Noise
Misfired rounds
controls:
Use proper hearing protection for the task.
Safety glasses and face shield shall be worn while operating tool.
Only a licensed operator shall operate a Powder Actuated tool.
All tools shall be inspected prior to use.
Shot strips shall be removed after the last shot has been fired.
Powder Actuated tools shall never be left unattended and stored in a controlled environment.
Misfired rounds will be stored on site in a fire rated box and taken to the company office to be disposed of.

task: Lift duct into place using mechanical means
hazards:
Working out of scissor lift /Mobil Electric Work Platform
Pinch points
Lacerations
Strains
controls:
Keep entire body inside basket area when moving/raising lift.
Ensure lower controls remain unobstructed.
Spotter knows how to operate emergency controls from the ground.
Complete daily checklist before use.
Identify pinch points.
Keep body out of area until material is where it needs to be to limit contact.
Wear cut-resistant gloves or cut resent liners.

hazards:
Duct sealing
Flying particles or debris
Sprains & strains
Pinch points
Lacerations
Noise
controls:
Use proper hearing protection for the task.
Work in proper ventilated area. Have SDS available in work area.
Wear safety goggles to protect against chips and ejected debris. Face shield wile drilling holes over head.
Proper lifting and material handling may include the use of carts, hand trucks and/or the buddy system.
Identify pinch points.
Stay out from under a suspended load until it is in place.
Wear cut-resistant gloves.

hazards:
Caught between
Contact with
Falls
Struck by
Lacerations
Foreign debris in eye
controls:
Before accessing the top of the duct work, it shall be supported with 4X4's and high jacks at the joints to support the additional load.
Set and secure ladder in place.
The worker shall climb the ladder to the top of the duct work.
Establish fall protection before getting on shaft.
Install plywood on top of the duct work to protect it from damage.
The worker shall crawl or slide themselves on top of the plywood to install fastening clips and sealant to the joints.

hazards:
Lacerations
Caught Between
Pinch Points
Sprains & Strains
Struck By
controls:
Put shaft duct together and line up bolt hole, insert bolt and tighten up.
Then seal section together.
Use the proper PPE for the task.

task: Install I-Beam on floor above to hook chain fall to
controls:
Use appropriate fall protection equipment and tie off point.
Position I-Beam in center of hole and secure.
Attach chain fall to beam.

task: Pulling duct into place with chain fall
hazards:
Overhead loads
Contact with
Poor communication
Faulty rigging
controls:
Inspect all rigging components prior to hoisting duct,
Do not stand under a suspended load. Create a CAZ if necessary.
Good clear communication.
Use proper fall protection for task at hand.

task: Create and work on scaffold planking
hazards:
Struck by
Caught between
Lacerations
Pinch points
Sprains & strains
Falls
controls:
Place rated scaffold planks across duct to avoid falling into duct.
Create a working surface of at least 18 inches or two planks wide.
Secure the planks from displacement
Use proper fall protection to avoid falls in gaps between duct and slab.
All openings shall be fully covered with planking and no opening's larger than 1 inch of a gap between planking.

hazards:
Falls
Others working overhead
Struck By
controls:
Use paint brush to install duct sealant on splices.
Be aware of the overhead surroundings.
Use proper fall protection methods and proper tie off.

hazards:
Falls
Multiple Injuries
Pinch Points
Struck By
Shifting of the platform
Dropped or Falling Objects
controls:
Employees shall not ride rolling scaffolds.
Caster brakes shall be applied at all times while worker is on the platform.
The height of a rolling scaffold must not exceed three times the least base dimension.
Scaffold must be inspected by competent person before each use.
Workers must receive scaffold-use training prior to use.
Only materials being used for work in progress shall be used on the scaffold. Do not overload the scaffold.

hazards:
Falls
Multiple Injuries
Pinch Points
Struck By
Failure of scaffold
Dropped or Falling Objects
controls:
Scaffold must be inspected by competent person before each use.
Ensure the green tag is current and document our inspection.
Workers must receive scaffold-use training prior to use.
Scaffold shall be designed to withstand four times the intended load.
At no times should scaffold loads exceed the manufacturer's recommendations.
Do not modify the scaffold -- let the [Customer] know if there are any problems or concerns.
Only materials being used for work in progress shall be used on the scaffold. Do not overload the scaffold.

task: Installation of Insulation, sound caulking, fire stopping
hazards:
Lacerations
Skin irritation
Foreign debris in eye
Slips, trips and falls
controls:
Wear the appropriate PPE for the task including a long sleeve shirt.
Wear a voluntary-use dust mask if desired (refer to Respirator Program for more information)
Pipe insulation will be cut to length using a contractors knife on the ground or on a cutting table.
When cutting insulation always cut away from the body.

task: Drill and set concrete anchor (if required)
hazards:
Exposure to silica dust
Flying Particles & Debris
Pinch Points
Tool bit binding up/Release of stored energy
controls:
Push anchor in as far as possible before hammering into place.
Keep free hand clear of anchor when hammering.
Use HEPA vacuum at point of drilling to remove silica dust.
Use a safety goggles and a face shield when drilling into concrete.
Use the tool in accordance with the operator's manual.
Position your body and hold the tool so binding will pull the tool away from the operator.

task: Cut strut and all-thread rod to size
hazards:
Cuts or Lacerations
Protruding sharp objects
controls:
If the hanger was prefabbed and a modification is needed, remove the hanger from the bracket before cutting.
Wear cut-resistant gloves when working with hanger materials.
Use vise to hold materials during cutting.
File sharp edges of rod and strut.
Place end caps on hanger pieces before installation.
Cut all-thread rod to minimum length to prevent protruding ends.

task: Installation of Duct Supports and Hangers
hazards:
Dropped or Falling Objects
Pinch Points
Slips, Trips and Falls
Lacerations
controls:
Create a CAZ when material or tools have a potential of falling on others in the area.
Use the proper PPE for the hazards exposed by the task.
Use fall protection whenever you are within 6' of a 6' or greater fall.
Protect other trades' products from trade damage.
Clean as you go.
